hints.content: Start by understanding the initial setup. There are `n` children, and they are indexed from `0` to `n-1`. The ball starts with child `0` and is passed to the right.
Consider how the ball is passed. For each second, the ball moves to the next child in line. If it reaches the last child (child `n-1`), it will reverse direction.
Think about the direction change. When the ball reaches child `0`, it changes direction to the right, and when it reaches child `n-1`, it changes direction to the left.
Try simulating the ball passing for a small value of `k`. For example, with `n = 3` and `k = 5`, track the ball's position second by second to see the pattern.
Notice that after `2 * (n - 1)` seconds, the ball will return to the starting position (child `0`). This is because it takes `n-1` seconds to go to the end and `n-1` seconds to come back.
Use the modulo operation to simplify the number of seconds. Instead of passing the ball for `k` seconds, you can use `k % (2 * (n - 1))` to find an equivalent smaller number of seconds.
After calculating `k % (2 * (n - 1))`, determine the position of the ball. If the result is less than `n`, the ball is simply at that index.
If the result of `k % (2 * (n - 1))` is greater than or equal to `n`, it means the ball has passed the last child and is coming back. You need to calculate its position on the way back.
When the ball is coming back, the position can be calculated as `2 * (n - 1) - (k % (2 * (n - 1)))`. This gives you the child index correctly.
Combine your findings into a final step. Use the reduced `k` to determine if the ball is moving forward or backward and calculate the final child index accordingly.

questionNotes: Children are indexed from 0 to n-1.
The ball starts with child 0 and is passed to the right.
The direction changes when the ball reaches either end of the line.
